quiz.title: Unit 4: Elasticity (Quiz 7)
quiz.subtitle: 4.7 Price Elasticity of Supply: Producer Responsiveness to Price (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Economics
quiz.topic: Price Elasticity of Supply, Producer Response, Time and Supply Elasticity

questions.question: Price elasticity of supply (PES) measures:
options: How quantity demanded responds to price changes
How quantity supplied responds to price changes
How demand responds to income changes
How supply responds to cost changes
questions.explanation: Price elasticity of supply measures the percentage change in quantity supplied divided by the percentage change in price - it shows how responsive producers are to price changes.

questions.question: The formula for price elasticity of supply is:
options: % change in quantity demanded / % change in price
% change in quantity supplied / % change in price
% change in price / % change in quantity supplied
Change in quantity supplied / change in price
questions.explanation: PES = (% change in quantity supplied) / (% change in price). This measures how sensitive producers are to price changes.

questions.question: Unlike demand elasticity, supply elasticity is typically:
questions.explanation: Supply elasticity is generally positive because of the direct relationship between price and quantity supplied - higher prices encourage more production.

questions.question: If supply is perfectly inelastic, the supply curve is:
questions.explanation: Perfectly inelastic supply means quantity supplied does not change at all when price changes, represented by a vertical supply curve.

questions.question: If a 10% price increase causes a 15% increase in quantity supplied, the PES is:
questions.explanation: PES = (% change in quantity supplied) / (% change in price) = 15% / 10% = 1.5

questions.question: Supply tends to be more elastic in the long run because:
options: Producers have more time to adjust their production capacity
questions.explanation: In the long run, producers can build new factories, hire more workers, and make other capacity adjustments, making supply more responsive to price changes.

questions.question: Which product would likely have the most inelastic supply in the short run?
options: Agricultural crops with fixed growing seasons
questions.explanation: Agricultural crops have highly inelastic short-run supply because production is constrained by biological growing seasons and cannot be quickly increased.

questions.question: Perfectly elastic supply is represented by:
questions.explanation: Perfectly elastic supply means producers will supply any quantity at a specific price but none at a lower price, represented by a horizontal supply curve.

questions.question: The main factor that makes supply more elastic is:
options: The ability to quickly increase production
questions.explanation: When producers can easily and quickly increase output in response to price changes, supply becomes more elastic.

questions.question: If PES = 0.8, supply is considered:
questions.explanation: PES less than 1 indicates inelastic supply - quantity supplied changes proportionally less than price changes.

questions.question: The momentary supply period refers to when:
options: Producers can fully adjust all inputs
Producers cannot change quantity supplied at all
Only some inputs can be adjusted
questions.explanation: In the momentary period, quantity supplied is fixed and cannot be changed regardless of price, making supply perfectly inelastic.

questions.question: Which industry typically has very elastic supply?
questions.explanation: Software distribution has highly elastic supply because additional copies can be produced at virtually zero marginal cost.

questions.question: If PES = 2.0 and price increases by 5%, quantity supplied will:
questions.explanation: PES = %ΔQs / %ΔP → 2.0 = %ΔQs / 5% → %ΔQs = 2.0 × 5% = 10% increase

questions.question: The availability of excess production capacity makes supply:
questions.explanation: When producers have idle capacity, they can quickly increase output in response to price increases, making supply more elastic.

questions.question: In the short run, supply is typically more inelastic because:
options: Producers face fixed factors of production
questions.explanation: In the short run, some factors of production are fixed (factory size, specialized equipment), limiting how quickly output can be increased.

questions.question: If supply is unit elastic (PES = 1), a 10% price increase will cause:
questions.explanation: With unit elastic supply, quantity supplied changes by the same percentage as price changes.

questions.question: The mobility of factors of production affects supply elasticity by:
options: Making supply more elastic when factors are mobile
Making supply more inelastic when factors are mobile
questions.explanation: When resources can easily move between different uses, producers can more quickly respond to price changes, making supply more elastic.

questions.question: Agricultural products often have inelastic supply because:
options: They are affected by biological constraints and weather
questions.explanation: Agricultural supply is constrained by growing seasons, weather conditions, and biological processes, making it difficult to quickly adjust production.

questions.question: The time period classification for supply elasticity includes:
options: Only short run and long run
Momentary, short run, and long run
questions.explanation: Supply elasticity is analyzed across three time periods: momentary (no adjustment), short run (some adjustment), and long run (full adjustment).

questions.question: Understanding supply elasticity helps policymakers predict:
options: How much prices will change when demand shifts
questions.explanation: Knowing supply elasticity helps predict price changes - when supply is inelastic, demand shifts cause larger price changes; when elastic, smaller price changes.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You thoroughly understand price elasticity of supply and how producers respond to price changes across different time periods.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You understand the basic concepts but review how time affects supply elasticity and the factors that make supply more or less elastic.
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on: PES measures producer response to price; More elastic over longer time periods; Constrained by production capacity and technology.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Remember that supply elasticity measures how quantity supplied responds to price changes, and this responsiveness increases with more time to adjust production.
